texts.definition: Cases where games falsely claim games are over to players.
markups: <style="Definition">Cases where games falsely claim games are over to players.</style>

Many games make player experience game over events. Those that do have the option to trick players by including Fake Game Overs to trick players into experiencing that they've failed only to then reveal that gameplay actually continues. TV Tropes discussed this pattern under the name Fission Mailed. It is also discussed in Zagal et al. as part of discussing definitions of dark game design patterns.

Examples of games that use <style="CurrentLink">Fake Game Overs</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Batman:%20Arkham%20Asylum">Batman: Arkham Asylum</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eternal%20Darkness:%20Sanity's%20Requiem">Eternal Darkness: Sanity's Requiem</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Metal%20Gear%20Solid%202:%20Sons%20of%20Liberty">Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty</link></style>.
<style="CurrentLink">Fake Game Overs</style> are used to make player believe they are experiencing a <style="Link"><link="game-over">Game Over</link></style> event when they in reality are not.

<style="CurrentLink">Fake Game Overs</style> are <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> and examples of <style="Link"><link="alternate-reality-gameplay">Alternate Reality Gameplay</link></style>. They create <style="Link"><link="fake-game-cancellations">Fake Game Cancellations</link></style> and by doing so, they create <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Fake Game Overs</style> are incompatible with <style="Link"><link="game-termination-penalties">Game Termination Penalties</link></style> just as they are in reality incompatible with <style="Link"><link="game-over">Game Over</link></style> events.
